timeline.bodyText: I would like to get a bit more of context about this exception handling and what it really implies for the system. So, in which circumstances this InvalidOffsetException can be thrown? As this defragmentation process is revisiting the chunks written some time back, would it be a synonym of a DataCorruptionException in Tier 2? For instance, related to chunks partially written? Because if this InvalidOffsetException is a symptom of a real problem with LTS data, maybe we could use this offline process to alert that something is wrong with Tier 2 data and stop IO in Pravega until the problem is fixed. Without this kind of audit or verification, could we get InvalidOffsetException (or other exceptions of the sort) from LTS chunks and Pravega would continue processing data, right?
timeline.author: RaulGracia

replies.bodyText:
We accidently encountered this issue while running longevity runs with wrong config.

In SLTS concat operation is 3 step process - first we merge the chunk metadata list ,  then we defragment the chunks in that list and then finally commit all metadata changes.
In this particular instance, the defragment operation was successful but the transaction to commit metadata failed. (because of internal error with table segment code).
This resulted in last chunk of target segment having all data from chunks of source segment but metadata still had old information.
When storage writer attempted the operation again, we found that for the last chunk of target segment the length on LTS did not match metadata and it correctly threw InvalidOffsetException
This results in unrecoverable error. SW can not make any progress and cache becomes full and everything comes to halt.



Note that we DO NOT delete source chunks unless commit was successful.


However this is a more generic failure mode and can happen for any of following reason

process crashed while doing defrag
some I/O error happened while doing defrag
the segment store failed over and the zombie instance continued to write to last chunk. (perfectly valid scenario for SLTS)
so on.



Such kind of error is not data corruption - this is a "normal" and valid circumstance .

The appropriate handling is to skip over the chunk with garbage data at the end.
This kind of situation should never block StorageWriter from making progress.
replies.author: sachin-j-joshi

timeline.bodyText: Is this validating the InvalidOffsetException, right? As it is not validating that such exception is thrown, it means that the  defragmentation will continue working as usual, skipping any number of such failures.
timeline.author: RaulGracia

replies.bodyText:
Yes. Here we are writing additional garbage data to chunk directly via ChunkStorage without SLTS knowing about it. And therefore SLTS tries to write at the wrong offset.
In this case the ChunkStorage contract requires it to throw InvalidOffsetException when write operation is called by SLTS with wrong offset - which it throws.
This way the test recreates the exact situation we are trying to fix.
replies.author: sachin-j-joshi

For others we just bubble them up.
